item.description: Whatever you believe in, bring wishes of kindness to those who suffer.

item.title: The lady on the Zoom call
item.description: The lady on your Zoom call: she has a soul. Find it. The AI that’s helping you. It has a soul. Never waste the possibility of Soul’s Existence.

item.title: Make it personal
item.description: The facade is the new form of communication. Avoid it. Spend the time to do something truly personal.

item.title: The people who say No
item.description: The only thing you need to remember is this: If someone wants to fight you, make sure you finish it.

item.title: The Rise and Fall of Rugged Individualism
item.description: Rugged Individualism taught us to ignore experience. For the good of everything and everyone else, keep going full bore.

item.description: Philosophers have argued over religion and spirituality for aeons, it seems. As the saying goes, are we cutting off our noses to spite our faces?

item.title: Meditations per Hour (MPH) or Meditation ROI?
item.description: If you have a goal for meditation, make sure it’s not MPH (Meditations per Hour) but M-ROI.

item.title: This is our GDPR Compliance Statement
item.description: WorldwideStew is committed to protecting the privacy of our users. This statement outlines our compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Data Collection: At this time, there is very limited tracking or cookie usage. Data Usage: To our knowledge, we are not using trackers. However, Google does track pageviews. any information we gather is used only for purposes of site operation and provision of services to the user. Data Protection: You have the option to use the site along with the limited cookies we gather and the possibility of tracking leading to and departing from Worldwide Stew.

item.title: Winning at the Shooting Range: layering for success
item.description: Self-esteem and success are related. A simple secret allows us to win at both.

item.title: Awe in a song
item.description: Driven by an unspeakable and unshakable certainty, the two characters find their separate paths to each other. And, to something both more terrifying and more wondrous than anything imaginable. What’s more? They must make decisions about what they’ve witnessed.

item.title: The Point of an Easter Egg
item.description: There’s nothing more creative than hiding something creative in plain sight. This is the idea of the Easter Egg. We can see them in surprising places. We just have to look.

item.description: Could a historical disagreement over a racist phrase provide a way forward in our angry, divided culture?

item.description: The Governor of Texas would disapprove. But, it’s time I came clean about my relationship with Claude.

item.title: The last thing they say before they leave
item.description: Too often, people wait until the very last second to say what they wanted, intended, and should have said the first thing.

item.title: Imagine this in a landfill
item.description: That cool thing you must have right now? How will it look in three years? Will you still be using it? Will it be in a landfill or yard sale?

item.title: Deep Dive: Suicide Crisis Syndrome
item.description: There are many methods of screening for suicide risk. The idea of the Suicide Crisis Syndrome appeals to me. It argues that depression or anxiety don’t explain all suicide experiences.

item.title: Deep Dive: AI, sleep, medical errors, Zionism, peace, and Passover

item.description: It had been a while since we’d seen each other. Age has crept up on us.

item.description: I don’t enjoy officiating at funerals, especially of someone I’ve loved. Sometimes, though, Fate…

item.title: Deep Dive: phone addictions; private equity and hospitals
item.description: This week’s featured articles From Harvard Business Review. Do you have a phone addiction? - uhh, probably. Now, do something about it. What happens when hospitals aren’t appropriately funded? They often turn to funding from Private Equity firms. What happens then? It’s not good and costs patients and society. Read this article from Harvard.

item.title: Deep Dive: Revisiting the work of chaplains
item.description: I worry about the relevance of chaplains in mode

item.title: Your chore list
item.description: We look forward to retirement as though the work just goes away. Rethink that plan.

item.title: Deep Dive: A questionable iOS feature; US Disease Burden from plastics; interesting recent articles
item.description: A review of news I find interesting. 1. An iOS feature you might want to fix. 2. It’s taken a long time for plastics to create what many believe will create significant human disease burden. That ship has gathered substantial steam. 3. Possiblle harms related to mindfulness (if your going to be in a mindfulness group, make sure the leader is qualified). 4. Watch out for marketing using neuro: they may be trying to get into your head. 5. A compassion therapy that can boost expansiveness? That just blows my mind (if it turns out to be good research).

item.title: Travel, health, and generations with Anthony Nguyen
item.description: In this first interview epidode of the Worldwide Stew podcast, I interviewed my friend, Anthony Nguyen, BSN, RN. He talks about travel (joys and travails), children, aging, the elderly, how to look at travel, and the role of chaaplains in acute pain.

item.title: Deep Dive: Ethics, psychiatry and industry funding; cool biodegradable coffins; Ubuntu; Chaplains replacing school counselors
item.description: “Is it okay for industry to fund the DSM-5-TR panel?; Is it okay for chaplains to replace school counselors?; Is it time to order your biodegradable coffin?; and, others!”

item.title: Soft Landings
item.description: Sometimes our beliefs - our certainties - come crashing down around us. How we weather those storms is dependent on the people…

item.title: The Beauty of Doubt
item.description: Don’t be so sure.

item.title: Deep Dive: Apple notifications and the Religious Right
item.description: I’ve liked my iPhone. Except for notifications. Google did them much better. But, that’s just an annoyance. The Religious Right and it’s efforts to create a love child with our political leaders is downright scary. We should be very scared. All of us. Even the good people who subscribe.

item.title: Deep Dive: Weight, self-criticism, and compassion-focused therapy
item.description: Shame, self-criticism, and obesity go hand in hand. Also, my first posted recipe reference in our new website digs.

item.title: Deep Dives: shame, smells, and shaming people
item.description: Shame drives us to great self-harm. Media is shame’s sledge hammer. Also, pay attention to the sense of smell!

item.title: Deep Dive: Lots more than I could put in a title
item.description: This week we look at psychological well-being - including from the U.S. Surgeon General, paying attention to the experience of detransitioners, exposomics, silence and epigenetics, Buddhism (religion or not), and my bone to pick with the Humanist Chaplaincy Network (I’m not picking any bones with humanist chaplains).

item.title: Deep Dive for 2024-02-25: Was COVID worse than the flu?
item.description: People who should have known to keep quiet until we had the data, told us that COVID was no worse than the flu. They were wrong

item.title: Deep Dive: Articles on contemplative practices and near death experiences
item.description: This week we consider recent research on mindfulness showing distinct patterns of contemplative practive help well-being. We also look at an article on the death experience during CPR. Maybe we shouldn’t blow off those near-death experiences so quickly.

item.title: Deep Dive: The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator
item.description: The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator, many other purported personality measurements falls short in terms of accuracy. In the wrong hands, it can be dangerous.

item.title: The glass is empty
item.description: The longer we live, the more apparent our wasted energy and time becomes. The alternative is focus and attention.

item.title: The Dunning-Kruger Effect
item.description: We all want to believe in the impossible. We, you and me, will never die. Or, at best, it’s will be far into the future: we don’t need to worry about it now. Nothing could be farther from the truth. This true story tells how wrogn our assumptions can be.

item.title: The Dunning-Kruger Effect
item.description: The bank robber was dismayed he was caught. He was certain the police could never catch him because he was wearing The Juice.

item.title: The Nature of Protection
item.description: Sometimes, we borrow the means to hide. Sometimes, they work. Other times, they don’t. The effort to protect ourselves seems forced by evolution. Maybe, though, we can do better. My profanity evolution…

item.title: The Point of Mindfulness Meditation
item.description: Working too hard at mindfulness meditation with little success? Maybe you’ve missed the point. Actually, points.

item.title: Fighting the same old battles
item.description: We tire of fighting the same old battles. Why should we? Are there reasons for summoning our will to continue?
